data.title: Cluster access
data.statement:
42 is an informatic school with a lot of computers. At Paris, there are 3 floors (called "clusters" (from 1 to 3) and described by the letter <<f>>), each is arranged like this (* is a computer):
`  1 2 3    4 5 6   7 8 9``1 * * *    * * *   * * *``2 * * *    * * *   * * *``3 * * *    * * *   * * *``4 * * *    * * *   * * *``...`
- Left entries are the rows (from 1 to 7, though only 4 shown), described by letter <<r>>
- Top entries are the seats (from 1 to 9), described by the letter <<s>>

So, every computer can be described by a name containing a floor, a row and a seat (ex: {{f2r5s6}} is the computer at the <<2nd floor, 5th row, 6th seat>>).

But we can describe a computer group without specifying the row or the seat, using identifiers:
An identifier is formatted by a series of letters and numbers (ex: {{r5f2}} is all the computers of the <<5th row>>, at the <<2nd floor>>). Letters can be in any order.

With an identifier we want to know all the IPs of the targeted computers. IPs used this format: <<10.1f.r.s>> (e.g. 10.13.2.1 for f3r2s1)
data.constraints:
Identifiers are always valid:
- Contains a floor
- Can contain a row
- Can contain a seat
- Never contains any other characters
data.outputDescription: On each line, print an [[IP]], sorted by row then by seat (f1r1s1, f1r1s2, ... f1r3s1, ... f1r7s9)

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

42 is an informatic school with a lot of computers. At Paris, there are 3 floors (called "clusters" (from 1 to 3) and described by the letter f), each is arranged like this (* is a computer):
  1 2 3    4 5 6   7 8 9
1 * * *    * * *   * * *
2 * * *    * * *   * * *
3 * * *    * * *   * * *
4 * * *    * * *   * * *
...

- Left entries are the rows (from 1 to 7, though only 4 shown), described by letter r
- Top entries are the seats (from 1 to 9), described by the letter s

So, every computer can be described by a name containing a floor, a row and a seat (ex: f2r5s6 is the computer at the 2nd floor, 5th row, 6th seat).

But we can describe a computer group without specifying the row or the seat, using identifiers:
An identifier is formatted by a series of letters and numbers (ex: r5f2 is all the computers of the 5th row, at the 2nd floor). Letters can be in any order.

With an identifier we want to know all the IPs of the targeted computers. IPs used this format: 10.1f.r.s (e.g. 10.13.2.1 for f3r2s1)
Input
Line 1 : An identifier
Output
On each line, print an IP, sorted by row then by seat (f1r1s1, f1r1s2, ... f1r3s1, ... f1r7s9)
Constraints
Identifiers are always valid:
- Contains a floor
- Can contain a row
- Can contain a seat
- Never contains any other characters
Example
Input
f2r1s1
Output
10.12.1.1
